parts:
How do I submit a sitemap to Google?

Can I upload a sitemap.xml to my public_html folder?

Here’s how you handle sitemap submission properly:

---

## 1. Generating and Placing the Sitemap
- Yes, you **can upload a `sitemap.xml` file** into your hosting root folder (on SiteGround this is usually `public_html/`).
- That way, it will be accessible at  
  ```
  https://yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml
  ```
- Make sure the sitemap is valid XML and follows the [sitemaps.org standard](https://www.sitemaps.org/protocol.html).

---

## 2. Submitting to Google
Google won’t automatically know about your sitemap just because the file exists. You have two options:

### A. Via Google Search Console (recommended)
1. Go to [Google Search Console](https://search.google.com/search-console/).
2. Add your domain property (if not already added and verified).
3. In the left menu, click **Sitemaps**.
4. Enter the sitemap URL, e.g.:
   ```
   https://yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml
   ```
5. Submit. Google will fetch and process it.  
   You can later check if it was crawled successfully.

### B. Via `robots.txt` (secondary method)
- In your `robots.txt` (which should also live in `public_html/`), add a line:
  ```
  Sitemap: https://yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml
  ```
- Example minimal robots.txt:
  ```
  User-agent: *
  Disallow:
  Sitemap: https://yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml
  ```

This doesn’t “submit” directly but signals search engines to look at it when crawling.

---

## 3. Best Practices
- Keep the sitemap up to date (regenerate if you add or remove lots of pages).
- Use absolute URLs (e.g., `https://yourdomain.com/page.html`).
- If your site is large, you can split into multiple sitemap files and use a **sitemap index**.
- Make sure your sitemap is publicly accessible (test in browser).

---

✅ So yes: upload `sitemap.xml` to `public_html/`, then **submit the URL in Google Search Console** and optionally reference it in `robots.txt`.

---

Do you want me to also show you how to **auto-generate a sitemap** for your static HTML + WordPress hybrid setup, so you don’t have to manually maintain it?
Do I need to remove outdated sitemap files left lying around?

Good question — here’s the situation:  

---

## 1. Outdated Sitemap Files
- If you have multiple sitemap files (say, `sitemap.xml`, `sitemap_old.xml`, `sitemap-test.xml`) sitting in `public_html/`, Google **may discover them** (e.g., through internal links, robots.txt references, or by brute-force guessing common names).  
- If they contain **bad URLs, duplicates, or URLs you no longer want indexed**, that can confuse crawlers and slightly hurt crawl efficiency.  
- If they’re harmless test files and **not referenced anywhere**, Google usually ignores them — but it’s still cleaner to remove them.

---

## 2. What You Should Do
- **Keep only the official sitemap(s):** the one(s) you actively maintain and submit in Search Console.  
- **Delete outdated sitemap files** if:
  - They contain dead or irrelevant URLs.  
  - They are no longer part of your SEO plan.  
- If you must keep an old one for some reason, ensure it’s not linked from `robots.txt` and not submitted in Search Console.

---

## 3. How Google Treats Them
- Google does not “punish” you for extra sitemaps, but **irrelevant or broken sitemaps waste crawl budget** and can cause unnecessary “Submitted URL not found” or “Excluded” reports in Search Console.  
- Clean, minimal signals = better crawl efficiency.

---

✅ **Best practice:** keep only one canonical `sitemap.xml` (or a sitemap index if needed), remove outdated ones from `public_html`, and make sure only the valid sitemap is referenced in `robots.txt` and Search Console.  

---

Would you like me to also suggest a **safe cleanup procedure** (so you can test which sitemap Google is still seeing before you delete the extras)?

I have only a few important pages, but many (100+) blog postings that are of only secondary importance. I will be adding more key pages (which I definitely want crawled) as time goes by, and also more blog postings, How should I organize my sitemap?

thoughts.content: To optimize your sitemap, create separate ones for main pages and blog posts, linking them in a sitemap index. Use the <lastmod> tag for recency, ignoring priority/changefreq. For hybrid setups, let WordPress auto-generate the post sitemap while manually creating the static one. Control crawling with robots, and be careful with file sizes!

parts:
Short answer: use a **sitemap index** that points to (at least) two child sitemaps—one small, “always-fresh” sitemap for your **key pages**, and one (or more) rotating sitemaps for **blog posts**. Keep the key-pages sitemap tiny and updated immediately when you add/edit those pages; split blog posts by year or by count.

Here’s a solid, future-proof layout for your case:

# Recommended structure

```
/sitemap_index.xml
  -> /sitemap-pages.xml          (your important, evergreen pages)
  -> /sitemap-posts-2025.xml     (blog posts for 2025)
  -> /sitemap-posts-2024.xml     (blog posts for 2024)
  -> ... (add a new posts-YYYY each year, or paginate if needed)
```

## 1) sitemap_index.xml
Use this as the only URL you submit in Search Console and reference in robots.txt.
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<sitemapindex xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
  <sitemap>
    <loc>https://yourdomain.com/sitemap-pages.xml</loc>
    <lastmod>2025-09-14</lastmod>
  </sitemap>
  <sitemap>
    <loc>https://yourdomain.com/sitemap-posts-2025.xml</loc>
    <lastmod>2025-09-14</lastmod>
  </sitemap>
  <sitemap>
    <loc>https://yourdomain.com/sitemap-posts-2024.xml</loc>
    <lastmod>2025-09-01</lastmod>
  </sitemap>
</sitemapindex>
```

## 2) sitemap-pages.xml (small & high-signal)
Only include the handful of pages that really matter (home, core landing pages, pricing, contact, cornerstone resources). Keep it under ~50 URLs; ideally <20.
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
  <url>
    <loc>https://yourdomain.com/</loc>
    <lastmod>2025-09-14</lastmod>
  </url>
  <url>
    <loc>https://yourdomain.com/jc-maths.html</loc>
    <lastmod>2025-09-10</lastmod>
  </url>
  <!-- add new key pages here, update lastmod when they change -->
</urlset>
```

## 3) Blog sitemaps (rotate by year or by count)
- Create **one posts sitemap per year** (e.g., `sitemap-posts-2025.xml`), or paginate in chunks of ≤50–1,000 URLs (protocol max is 50,000, but smaller files are faster to fetch and simpler to manage).
- Update `lastmod` per post when you edit it.

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
  <url>
    <loc>https://yourdomain.com/blog/why-jc-math-foundations-matter</loc>
    <lastmod>2025-09-12</lastmod>
  </url>
  <!-- one entry per post published in 2025 -->
</urlset>
```

# Why this works (and what it doesn’t do)

- **Discovery & freshness**: Google checks small files more readily. Keeping a tiny `sitemap-pages.xml` ensures new/edited key pages are noticed quickly when `lastmod` changes.
- **Crawl efficiency**: Splitting posts by year keeps each file stable and fast; Google can fetch only the *current* year’s file frequently, and older years rarely.
- **Signals, not ranking**: Sitemaps don’t “boost” priority directly. To really emphasize key pages, also:
  - Link them prominently in header/footer and from related blog posts.
  - Keep them fast, cleanly structured, and internally well-linked.

# Practical tips for your hybrid (static + WordPress) setup

- **Generation**
  - Let **WordPress** generate the posts sitemaps (native or with a trusted SEO plugin). Most WP setups already expose `/sitemap.xml` and `/post-sitemap.xml` variants; you can **map or copy** those into your scheme or just include the WP post sitemaps directly in your index.
  - Generate the **static pages sitemap** from your build/script (or maintain a small hand-edited XML—it’s tiny).
- **Canonical URLs**: Ensure every URL in any sitemap is the canonical, HTTPS, non-dup version (no tracking params, no mixed trailing slashes).
- **lastmod only**: Include `<lastmod>` and skip `changefreq`/`priority`—Google largely ignores those today.
- **Exclude low-value pages**: Don’t list tag/category archives or thin pagination pages if they aren’t useful landing pages.
- **robots.txt**
  ```
  User-agent: *
  Disallow:
  Sitemap: https://yourdomain.com/sitemap_index.xml
  ```
- **Location**: Put all sitemap files in `public_html/` (or any publicly reachable path) and serve them compressed (GZIP) if your host supports it.

# Rollout procedure

1. Create `sitemap-pages.xml` with only the important pages.
2. Point your **sitemap index** to `sitemap-pages.xml` and your **current-year posts** sitemap(s).
3. Update robots.txt to reference **only** the index.
4. Submit **only** `https://yourdomain.com/sitemap_index.xml` in Search Console.
5. When a new key page goes live, add it to `sitemap-pages.xml` and bump its `<lastmod>`.
6. Each January, start a new `sitemap-posts-YYYY.xml`; leave past years untouched.

If you want, I can draft the files for your current URL set (pages + the 100+ blog posts) based on a quick list of your URLs.

I have a wordpress installation coexisting with my HTML files. The wordpress files like index.php are not supposed to be loaded -- only my index.html file is to be loaded when domain is visited. Can I delete those extra php files while retaining the ability to perform CRUD operations on wordpress posts and pages, and perform standard wordpress operations like plugin installation & update, registration of users, etc?

thoughts.content: You can't just delete the core PHP files in WordPress; they’re essential for its functionality. Even with an index.html front page, PHP is required for admin tasks like CRUD operations. Instead, you could move WordPress to a subdirectory or subdomain, adjust routing, and block public access using server rules.

To load index.html first, you can adjust Apache’s DirectoryIndex settings through .htaccess. You’ll need to block access to non-essential PHP files and control front-end routes (e.g., 404 redirects). Another option is using WordPress headless with a plugin. The simplest method is to move WordPress to a subdirectory or rewrite conditions.

Since WordPress will only serve as a blog repository, the user can move it to a subdirectory like /wp or /cms. Set the WordPress Address and Site Address accordingly. They should block the front-end theme and expose only admin and API routes with specific URL rules using .htaccess. It's essential to retain core PHP files for functionality.

To streamline WordPress: safely delete unused themes and plugins, but keep core files intact. Prioritize `index.html` using the `.htaccess DirectoryIndex` directive. Allow REST API access for CRUD operations, and ensure security with IP allowlists and CAPTCHA for `wp-login.php`. Avoid removing `index.php` since it plays a crucial routing role.

parts:
Short, direct answer: **No — don’t delete WordPress core PHP files.**  
All CRUD operations (posts/pages), plugin/theme install/updates, users, and the REST API **depend on those PHP scripts** (`index.php`, `wp-login.php`, `wp-admin/*.php`, `wp-includes/*.php`, `wp-json` bootstrap, `admin-ajax.php`, etc.). Removing them will break WordPress.

Here’s how to keep your static HTML as the public face while retaining full WP functionality:

# Recommended architecture (safe & clean)
**Put WordPress in a subdirectory** (e.g., `/cms/` or `/blog/`) and keep your static site at the root.

1) **Move WP into a subdir (e.g., `/public_html/cms/`)**  
   - Update **Settings → General** in WP:  
     - *WordPress Address (URL)*: `https://yourdomain.com/cms`  
     - *Site Address (URL)*: `https://yourdomain.com/cms`  
   - Fix permalinks after moving: **Settings → Permalinks → Save** once.
   - If needed, update `wp-config.php` and `.htaccess` paths (WordPress codex “Giving WordPress its own directory”).

2) **Serve your static homepage**  
   - Keep your `index.html` at root (`/public_html/index.html`).
   - Ensure Apache prefers HTML over PHP:
     ```apache
     # /public_html/.htaccess
     DirectoryIndex index.html index.htm index.php
     ```
   - This guarantees `index.html` is used at `https://yourdomain.com/`.

3) **Use WordPress only for data/admin**  
   - Your static pages fetch posts via REST:  
     `https://yourdomain.com/cms/wp-json/wp/v2/posts?...`
   - You (admins) use: `https://yourdomain.com/cms/wp-admin/`.

4) **Keep crawlers out of the WP front-end** (optional but tidy)
   - In your **root** `robots.txt`:
     ```
     User-agent: *
     Disallow: /cms/wp-admin/
     Disallow: /cms/wp-includes/
     Disallow: /cms/wp-content/plugins/
     Disallow: /cms/wp-content/themes/
     Sitemap: https://yourdomain.com/sitemap_index.xml
     ```
   - (If you don’t want any WP-rendered pages indexed at all, also disallow `/cms/` paths that render themes. Your REST endpoints will still function for your static site.)

5) **Harden security**
   - Block PHP execution in uploads:
     ```apache
     # /public_html/cms/wp-content/uploads/.htaccess
     <FilesMatch "\.php$">
       Deny from all
     </FilesMatch>
     ```
   - Optionally **IP-allowlist** or rate-limit `/cms/wp-login.php` and `/cms/wp-admin/`.  
   - Keep one default theme as a fallback; delete unused themes/plugins.

# Alternative (keep WP in root, still show index.html)
Not as clean, but possible if you can’t move WP now.

- Keep **all WP PHP files intact**.  
- Force `index.html` to win:
  ```apache
  DirectoryIndex index.html index.htm index.php
  ```
- Prevent most front-end WP routes being publicly browsable, while **allowing admin and REST**:
  ```apache
  RewriteEngine On

  # Always allow admin, login, REST, admin-ajax
  RewriteRule ^wp-admin/ - [L]
  RewriteRule ^wp-login\.php$ - [L]
  RewriteRule ^wp-json/ - [L]
  RewriteRule ^wp-admin/admin-ajax\.php$ - [L]

  # If the request is for a typical front-end WP route, block it
  # (adjust if you truly need some front-end path)
  RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} ^/(category|tag|author|page|post|archives|feed|comments) [NC]
  RewriteRule . - [F]

  # Otherwise fall through to static files (index.html already preferred)
  ```
  Be careful: over-blocking here can break plugins or custom endpoints. The subdirectory approach is safer.

---

## What you *can* safely delete
- Unused **themes** (keep one default like Twenty Twenty-Four as a fallback).
- Unused **plugins** (delete, don’t just deactivate).
- Sample content (hello world post), `hello.php` plugin, etc.

## What you should **not** delete
- `index.php` at the WordPress root (in the WP install directory)
- Anything under `wp-admin/` or `wp-includes/`
- `wp-login.php`, `admin-ajax.php`, REST bootstrap
- Any core file required by plugins/themes

---

### Bottom line
- **Do not delete** WordPress PHP core files if you want CRUD, plugins, users, and updates to work.  
- **Best practice:** put WP in `/cms/`, serve your static site at root, and use WP purely as a headless backend (REST), with indexing controls to keep WP front-end out of search.  
- Keep `DirectoryIndex` set so your `index.html` always wins at the domain root.

How do I move wordpress to a subdirectory?

My current HTML files (at the root) load and display blog postings.

Great — you want WordPress to run “headless” (back-end only) in a subdirectory, while your **root HTML site** stays public and continues to pull blog posts through WP’s API.  

Here’s the correct way to move your installation without breaking CRUD or your blog feed:

---

# 1. Preparation
- **Backup everything** (files + database) before making changes.  
- Make sure your HTML pages are already serving from `/public_html/` root.  
- Confirm you can log in to WP Admin (`https://yourdomain.com/wp-admin/`).

---

# 2. Create the Subdirectory
- Inside `public_html/`, create a folder, e.g. `/public_html/cms/`.  
- This will become the new WordPress home.

---

# 3. Move WordPress Core Files
- Move all WordPress files/folders from root into `/cms/`:  
  - `index.php`, `wp-admin/`, `wp-content/`, `wp-includes/`, etc.  
- Leave your static files (`index.html`, CSS, JS, images, etc.) untouched in root.

Now your structure looks like:
```
/public_html/index.html   (your static landing page)
/public_html/css/...      
/public_html/js/...       
/public_html/assets/...   

/public_html/cms/index.php
/public_html/cms/wp-admin/
...
```

---

# 4. Update WordPress Configuration
1. Open `/cms/wp-config.php`.  
   Ensure the following lines reflect the new location (if not already correct):
   ```php
   define('WP_HOME', 'https://yourdomain.com/cms');
   define('WP_SITEURL', 'https://yourdomain.com/cms');
   ```
   (These override database values.)

2. Alternatively, go into **WP Admin → Settings → General** (before moving) and set:  
   - **WordPress Address (URL)**: `https://yourdomain.com/cms`  
   - **Site Address (URL)**: `https://yourdomain.com/cms`

3. After moving, log back in at `https://yourdomain.com/cms/wp-admin/`.

---

# 5. Update Permalinks
- Go to **WP Admin → Settings → Permalinks → Save** (even if unchanged).  
  This regenerates `.htaccess` with the new base paths.

---

# 6. Make Static HTML the Domain Default
In `/public_html/.htaccess` at the root, ensure:
```apache
DirectoryIndex index.html index.htm index.php
```
This guarantees your `index.html` is served at `https://yourdomain.com/` instead of WP’s index.php.

---

# 7. Update Your HTML Blog Loader
Your HTML files that fetch blog posts should now point to:
```
https://yourdomain.com/cms/wp-json/wp/v2/posts
```
instead of `/wp-json/...`.  
Test this in browser — you should see JSON output.

---

# 8. Optional: Block Search Engines from WP Frontend
If you don’t want Google to crawl WP’s theme output:
- In root `robots.txt`:
  ```
  User-agent: *
  Disallow: /cms/wp-admin/
  Disallow: /cms/wp-includes/
  Sitemap: https://yourdomain.com/sitemap_index.xml
  ```
- If you want **only** API access, you can disallow `/cms/` entirely except `/cms/wp-json/`.  

---

# 9. Test Everything
- Visit `https://yourdomain.com/` → should load your static `index.html`.  
- Visit `https://yourdomain.com/cms/wp-admin/` → WP dashboard works.  
- Visit `https://yourdomain.com/cms/wp-json/wp/v2/posts` → JSON feed loads.  
- Verify CRUD operations (create/edit post, install plugin, add user).

---

✅ After this, WordPress is fully functional in `/cms/`, your HTML site runs from root, and you control exactly how blog posts display.  

---

Do you want me to also draft the **Apache rewrite rules** to block *all* direct access to WP’s theme/front-end (so only API + admin remain exposed)? That’s often a good next step in a hybrid setup like yours.
